questiontext.text: Set up a PCR with a total reaction volume of 25 µl. The stock concentration of the reverse primer is 10 nM. If 1.5 µl of reverse primer is added to the reaction, what is the final concentration of the reverse primer?
How many times are you likely to find a specific 12 base pair sequence within the 2,800 Mb mouse genome?

You have just performed a DNA cleanup of a PCR fragment. You make a 2 µl dilution of your DNA sample in to a final volume of 20 µl. Using a NanoDrop spectrophotometer you measure A260 to be 0.872. Calculate the concentration of your DNA sample (in µg/µl).
How many times are you likely to find a specific 18 base pair sequence within the 2,800 Mb mouse genome?

answer.text: 4.075 x 10-3
4.075 x 10-2

questiontext.text: 18/20 amino acids have more than one codon, looking at the genetic code in your lab manual you will see that some amino acids have as many as 6 codons. Thus a single amino acid sequence can be formed by many different DNA sequences, this is known as degeneracy. Degenerate primers can be used to clone a gene homologue from an unstudied species so long as the amino acid sequence is known for its gene homologue in the well studied species. Degenerate primers are designed at areas of amino acid conservation to increase the chance of getting a PCR product from the unsequenced species. As well as requiring a conserved region, an area of low degeneracy is preferred. From the conserved sequence below give the consecutive 8 amino acids which have the lowest degeneracy and will be used to form one of your degenerate primers. [Tip - use a pencil and paper.] YHQMASRWKMTDECRFIWFGMQHYEILNCTWFQTVGSHRE

You have just performed a restriction digest of your PCR product followed by a DNA cleanup. You quantify your DNA prior to a ligation reaction. Your DNA has a concentration of 38 ng/µl. In a 20 µl ligation reaction you wish to add 50 ng of cleaned up and digested PCR product, how many µl of product do you add to the reaction?

You are setting up a ligation reaction. You are cloning a 1 Kb insert into a 2 Kb plasmid. In the ligation you are using 250 ng of plasmid DNA, how much insert do you need to add to ensure there is a 2:1 ratio of insert : plasmid?

You are setting up a 20 µl ligation reaction. You are cloning an insert of 600 bp into a 2.4 Kb plasmid. The concentration of your insert is 50 ng/µl. The plasmid concentration is 200 ng/µl. You add to your reaction 1 µl of plasmid. What volume of insert do you add in order to achieve a 2:1 ratio of insert : plasmid?

As a control you transform an intact pBluescript, along with your ligation product. In the control transformation you use 1 µl of 25 pg/ µl in a final volume of 250 µl of L-Broth (after the expression step). You spread 50 µl of your transformation on an L-agar plate which has on it the appropriate antibiotic. After 24 hours at 37°C, the plate has 75 colonies. Use this information on the control to determine the transformation efficiency, express in transformants per µg of plasmid. You will need your lab manual to help you.

In a transformation control, 2 µl of pBluescript plasmid at a concentration of 3.5 pg/µl is added to chemically competent cells. The total volume of the transformation was 250 µl, only 75 µl was spread on a AMP + X-GAL plate.  After 24 hrs there were 128 ampicillin resistant, blue colonies on the plate. Calculate the transformation efficiency in transformants/µg.

You are picking positive colonies from your transformation plates to set up overnight cultures in 10 ml of L-broth plus the appropriate antibiotic. Your antibiotic stock concentration is 20 mg/ml, you require a final concentration of 50 µg/ml. How much stock do you add to the L-broth?

After carrying out a miniprep extraction of a 4.2 Kb plasmid, you quantify the DNA. The concentration is 85 ng/µl. You then digest with BamHI and EcoRI, each enzyme "cuts" the plasmid once resulting in two fragments of 1.6 Kb and 2.6 Kb. You run 5 µl of the digest on a gel. Approximately how much DNA is in the lower band?

answer.text: 32.4 ng
52.3 ng

questiontext.text: You are setting up a PCR reaction in a final volume of 50 µl. The stock concentration of your forward primer is 15 nM. How much forward primer must be added to get a final concentration of 0.3 nM?

Tris-EDTA (TE) buffer is commonly used in molecular biology, particularly when preparing DNA samples for storage, as this buffer protects DNA from degradation. Using a stock solution of 0.5 M Tris-HCl and a stock solution of 100 mM EDTA, prepare 100 ml of TE buffer which has 10 mM Tris and 1 mM EDTA.

answer.text: Add 1 ml of Tris-HCl stock to 1 ml of EDTA stock and top up to 100 ml with distilled H2O
Add 2 ml of Tris-HCl stock to 1 ml of EDTA stock and top up to 100 ml with distilled H2O
Add 1 ml of Tris-HCl stock to 1 ml of EDTA stock and add 100 ml with distilled H2O
Add 2 ml of Tris-HCl stock to 0.5 ml of EDTA stock and top up to 100 ml with distilled H2O
Add 2 ml of Tris-HCl stock to 1 ml of EDTA stock and add 100 ml with distilled H2O

questiontext.text: MgSO4 is an important compound in PCR as it stabilizes primer-template complexes. You are about to run a PCR but realise that you have no MgSO4 left. To resolve this you decide to make your own. The molecular weight of MgSO4 is 120.366 g/mol. Prepare 50 ml of a 25 mM stock solution.

answer.text: Add 0.15 g of MgSO4 to 45 ml of sterile H2O, dissolve fully and make up to 50 ml with more water
Add 1.5 g of MgSO4 to 50 ml of sterile H2O
Add 1.5 g of MgSO4 to 45 ml of sterile H2O, dissolve fully and make up to 50 ml with more water
Add 0.15 g of MgSO4 to 50 ml of sterile H2O
Add 0.3 g of MgSO4 to 45 ml of sterile H2O, dissolve fully and make up to 50 ml with more water

questiontext.text: Prepare a 75 ml 1% agarose gel using 25x TAE buffer.

answer.text: Add 6 ml of TAE to 69 ml of sterile H2O and mix. Pour 1x TAE into a bottle containing 0.75 g of agarose, melt your gel and pour
Add 3 ml of TAE to 72 ml of sterile H2O and mix. Pour 1x TAE into a bottle containing 0.75 g of agarose, melt your gel and pour
Add 3 ml of TAE to 72 ml of sterile H2O and mix. Pour 1x TAE into a bottle containing 1.5 g of agarose, melt your gel and pour once the gel cools to 50°C
Add 3 ml of TAE to 72 ml of sterile H2O and mix. Pour 1x TAE into a bottle containing 1.125 g of agarose, melt your gel and pour once the gel cools to 50°C
Add 3 ml of TAE to 72 ml of sterile H2O and mix. Pour 1x TAE into a bottle containing 0.75 g of agarose, melt your gel and pour once the gel cools to 50°C

questiontext.text: A plasmid can also be extracted from an overnight culture using the alkaline lysis method. This follows much of the same principles as modern day kits. In this method a lysis buffer is used to burst open the cells. The lysis buffer composition is 1% sodium dodecyl sulphate (SDS) and 0.2 M NaOH. Using a stock concentration of 10% SDS and 1 M NaOH make 100 ml of lysis buffer.

answer.text: add 10 ml of SDS stock to 20 ml of NaOH stock, add 100 ml of sterile H2O
add 5 ml of SDS stock to 20 ml of NaOH stock, top up to 100 ml with sterile H2O
add 10 ml of SDS stock to 40 ml of NaOH stock, top up to 100 ml with sterile H2O
add 10 ml of SDS stock to 20 ml of NaOH stock, top up to 100 ml with sterile H2O
add 20 ml of SDS stock to 20 ml of NaOH stock, add 100 ml of sterile H2O

questiontext.text: The alkaline lysis method also involves an isotonic resuspension buffer, the composition of which is:- 50 mM glucose, 25 mM Tris-HCl and 10 mM EDTA. In order make this buffer, stock solutions for each of the three components are required. What weight of each compound is required to make 500 ml stocks at concentrations of 0.5 M for (i) glucose, 0.5 M for (ii) Tris-HCl and 0.1 M for (iii) EDTA, given the molecular weights of these compounds are 180.16 g/mol, 121.14 g/mol, and 292.24 g/mol, respectively.

answer.text: (i) 45.04 g (ii) 29.648 g (iii) 14.612
(i) 90.08 g (ii) 60.57 g (iii) 29.224 g
(i) 45.04 g; (ii) 30.285 g; (iii) 14.612 g
(i) 42.06 g; (ii) 30.285 g; (iii) 14.612 g
(i) 45.04 g; (ii) 30.285 g; (iii) 16.412 g

questiontext.text: Quite often in the lab we store overnight cultures in the -80°C freezer. This means we don't need to constantly re-clone things and is one of the joys of working with bacteria. A common method for preparing cultures to go into the freezer is to add glycerol to your sample. In a final volume of 1 ml prepare a 2:1 ratio of culture to glycerol. Give the correct volumes of culture and glycerol used.

answer.text: 0.6 ml of culture + 0.4 ml of glycerol in a micro-centrifuge tube
0.67 ml of culture + 0.33 ml of glycerol in a micro-centrifuge tube
0.33 ml of culture + 0.67 ml of glycerol in a micro-centrifuge tube
0.4 ml of culture + 0.6 ml of glycerol in a micro-centrifuge tube
0.5 ml of culture + 0.5 ml of glycerol in a micro-centrifuge tube

questiontext.text: 1/2 Murashige and Skoog (MS) medium is commonly used to culture plants. It contains the macro and micro nutrients required for growth, as well as the food and energy source courtesy of sucrose. In 500 ml of medium there is 5 g of sucrose. What is the molarity of sucrose in this case given it has a molecular weight of 342.3 g/mol?

answer.text: 29.2 mM
14.6 mM
28.4 mM
1.5 mM
16.4 mM

questiontext.text: Prepare a 25 ml stock solution of 50 mg/ml carbenicillin in 40% ethanol.

answer.text: Add 10 ml of sterile H2O to 15 ml of ethanol. Add the 40% ethanol to a tube containing 0.625 g of carbenicillin. Separate into aliquots and store at -20°C
Add 15 ml of sterile H2O to 10 ml of ethanol. Add the 40% ethanol to a tube containing 0.625 g of carbenicillin. Separate into aliquots and store at -20°C
Add 15 ml of sterile H2O to 10 ml of ethanol. Add the 40% ethanol to a tube containing 1.25 g of carbenicillin. Separate into aliquots and store at -20°C
Add 20 ml of sterile H2O to 5 ml of ethanol. Add the 40% ethanol to a tube containing 0.625 g of carbenicillin. Separate into aliquots and store at -20°C
Add 12.5 ml of sterile H2O to 12.5 ml of ethanol. Add the 40% ethanol to a tube containing 1.25 g of carbenicillin. Separate into aliquots and store at -20°C

questiontext.text: You have been asked to prepare a 75 mg/ml stock concentration of ampicillin. Out of curiosity you want to determine the molarilty of this stock, given the molecular weight of ampicillin is 349.406 g/mol.

answer.text: 342 mM
0.107 M
430 mM
1.246 M
215 mM

questiontext.text: You have a stock concentration of chloramphenicol with a concentration of 34 mg/ml. You require a final concentration on your plates of 20 µg/ml. What volume of stock antibiotic do you add to 250 ml of molten L-agar?

answer.text: 136.7 µl
250 µl
147.1 µl
294.2 µl
273.4 µl

questiontext.text: Set up a PCR with a total reaction volume of 25 µl. Use:- 2X PCR master mix (includes MgSO4, dNTPs, buffer, dye, Taq Polymerase); forward and reverse primers both at stock concentrations of 7.5 nM; 1 µl of template DNA; and sterile H2O. The final concentration of both the forward and reverse primers must be 0.6 mM. What volume of each of the above ingredients are added to set up this PCR?

PCR Master Mix

F Primer R Primer Template Sterile H2O

questiontext.text: You have a stock concentration of plasmid DNA at 2.2 mg/ml. Prepare 12 ml of plasmid DNA at a concentration of 150 ng/ µl. The plasmid DNA will be separated into aliquots and used in a number of experiments including as a transformation control.

answer.text: Add 81.82 µl of stock DNA to 11.91818 ml of sterile H2O
Add 818.2 µl of stock DNA to 11.1818 ml of sterile H2O
Add 776.4 µl of stock DNA to 11.2236 ml of sterile H2O
Add 77.64 µl of stock DNA to 11.92236 ml of sterile H2O
Add 776.4 µl of stock DNA to 11.2436 ml of sterile H2O

questiontext.text: You are setting up a PCR reaction however the kit you are using here is NOT pre-made. Use the following essential ingredients to set up your reaction (in brackets are the final concentrations):- the forward and reverse primers at a stock concentration of 10 nM (0.4 nM); MgSO4 at a stock concentration of 25 mM (1 mM); 10X PCR buffer stock (1X); mix of dNTPs at a stock concentration of 2 mM each - all in one tube - (0.2 mM); DNA polymerase at a stock concentration of 1 U/µl (0.02 U/µl). Add to this 1 µl of template DNA and make up to 50 µl with sterile H2O. What volume of each of the above ingredients do you add to achieve the desired final concentrations?

answer.text:
For Primer Rev Primer MgSO4 buffer dNTPs polymerase Template Sterile H2O

2 µl

questiontext.text: You are performing a PCR reaction using Drosophila melanogaster genomic DNA as template. At the start of the reaction there are 12,000 copies of ds template DNA. How many copies of your target DNA are there after 25 reaction cycles?

answer.text: 4.0265 x 1010
4.0265 x 1011
1.2583 x 1010

questiontext.text: In cloning we often use restriction enzymes like KpnI which recognise 6 bp target sites. Assume that a double stranded plasmid - 25 Kb in size - has a completely randomised DNA sequence. How many times will an enzyme like KpnI cut this plasmid? Include 1 decimal place in your answer.

In cloning we often use restriction enzymes like KpnI which recognise 6 bp target sites. Assume that a double stranded plasmid - 25 Kb in size - has a completely randomised DNA sequence. How many times will an enzyme like KpnI cut this plasmid?

You are designing primers. An absolute necessity in primer design is that your sequence is long enough to be unique in the genomic DNA used as template. How many times are you likely to find a specific 12 base pair sequence within the 4.6 million bp (Mb) genome of Escherichia coli?
How many times are you likely to find a specific 18 base pair sequence within the 4.6 million bp (Mb) genome of Escherichia coli?

Following a DNA cleanup of a PCR fragment you use a NanoDrop to measure A260 and A280. You get the following readings:- A260 = 0.745, and, A280 = 0.486. Answer the following statement True or False:- Your DNA sample is pure and free from protein contamination therefore you can reliably use it for cloning purposes.

feedback.text: Try again, remember for a pure DNA preparation we are looking for a A260 / A280 of between 1.8 - 2.0
